\providecommand{\tabularnewline}{\\}

  {\def\RSsubtxt{section~}\newref{sub}{name = \RSsubtxt}}
  {}
\RS@ifundefined{thmref}
  {\def\RSthmtxt{theorem~}\newref{thm}{name = \RSthmtxt}}
  {}
\RS@ifundefined{lemref}
  {\def\RSlemtxt{lemma~}\newref{lem}{name = \RSlemtxt}}
  {}

\newenvironment{lyxlist}[1]
{\begin{list}{}
{\settowidth{\labelwidth}{#1}
 \setlength{\leftmargin}{\labelwidth}
 \addtolength{\leftmargin}{\labelsep}
 \renewcommand{\makelabel}[1]{##1\hfil}}}
{\end{list}}

\begin{document}

\title{\emph{Open Innovation Projects} website}

\maketitle
open-innovation-projects.org (\emph{OIP} in the text following) lists
mostly OSHW projects and systematically categorizes them. Out of the
\textsubscript{\textasciitilde{}}150 listed entries, the following
109 retained our attention in the context of OSHWL (\tabref{OIP-entries-treated}):

We will also apply the same ``standardized'' categorization effort
to the following OSHW(L) projects, not listed by OIP (\tabref{OSHWL-projects-categorized}):

\begin{table}[H]
{\footnotesize }%
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline 
{\footnotesize title} & {\footnotesize OSHWL path}\tabularnewline
\hline 
\hline 
 & \tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}{\footnotesize \par}

\caption{other OSHWL projects categorized according to OIP's method\label{tab:OSHWL-projects-categorized}}
\end{table}
\pagebreak{}

The following is the categorization itself (in tables making overview
and comparison easy, as opposed to individual project sheets as is
the case on open-innovation-projects.org), copied from OIP for the
projects they list and complemented (\emph{italic}) with the projects
from \tabref{OSHWL-projects-categorized}.

There are three groups of criteria:
\begin{itemize}
\item project details
\item product details
\item institutional design and production
\end{itemize}

\section*{Project details}

\framebox{\begin{minipage}[t]{0.9\textwidth}%

\subsection*{Legend}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Project Type}}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{{\footnotesize S}}] {\footnotesize One or more specific product(s)
is/are shown and/or developed }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize C}}] {\footnotesize Overview over several different
projects or product, e.g. OIP itself}{\footnotesize \par}
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Development Status}}

{\footnotesize Current stage of development according to the following:}{\footnotesize \par}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{{\footnotesize 1}}] {\footnotesize Planning/Virtual development
- Ideas and digital dev. evolving }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize 2}}] {\footnotesize Prototyping started - First
physical proto. assembled, testing phase }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize 3}}] {\footnotesize First working proto. - Working
proto. av., release to community, further dev. needed }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize 4}}] {\footnotesize Production stable - Fully functional
product permanently av. on market, further dev. possible }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize 5}}] {\footnotesize Mature - Final dev. stage reached,
no further dev. necessary }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize Inactive}}] {\footnotesize Dev. stopped, no final
product av.}{\footnotesize \par}
\end{lyxlist}
{\footnotesize In case several products are being developed, the stage
of the most advanced product is indicated. }{\footnotesize \par}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Community}}

{\footnotesize Approximate community size or number of users involved. }{\footnotesize \par}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Developers}}

{\footnotesize Approximate number of active developers. }{\footnotesize \par}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize License}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {\footnotesize whether the project is using an open license and of
which type}{\footnotesize \par}
\item {\footnotesize whether they have a registered trademark}{\footnotesize \par}
\end{itemize}

\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Country}}

{\footnotesize Main location, i.e. home country of the project leader,
the core team or the office location. }{\footnotesize \par}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Start year}}

{\footnotesize Year in which the project was initiated.}{\footnotesize \par}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Intended Audience}}

{\footnotesize Target group of the project according to the following
criteria: }{\footnotesize \par}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{{\footnotesize EU}}] \noindent {\footnotesize Everybody from school
kids to your grandmother. }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize AEU}}] \noindent {\footnotesize Product will target
end users, but usage may require specific knowledge. }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize Developer}}] {\footnotesize No intention to reach
end users, high specific knowledge necessary. }{\footnotesize \par}
\item [{{\footnotesize Other}}] {\footnotesize All other groups, for example
educational purposes }{\footnotesize \par}
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Project contact}}

{\footnotesize Project contact person and/or address}{\footnotesize \par}


\paragraph{\textrm{\footnotesize Keywords}}

{\footnotesize Comma separated list of keywords. The title of another
project can be used.}%
\end{minipage}}

\pagebreak{}


\section*{Product details}

\framebox{\begin{minipage}[t]{1\columnwidth}%

\subsection*{{\small Legend}}


\paragraph*{{\small Product innovativeness}}

{\small Degree of innovativeness according to the following criteria: }{\small \par}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{{\small 5}}] {\small Radical innovation - a new technology that
results in a new market infrastructure, e.g. an innovation which does
not address a recognized demand but instead creates a demand previously
unrecognized by the consumer }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small 4}}] {\small Really new innovation - a really new product
results in a market discontinuity or a technological discontinuity
but will not incorporate both, e.g., new product lines, product line
extensions with new technology, or new markets with existing technology }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small 3}}] {\small Discontinous innovations - new technologies
that don't lead to discontinuity in existing markets }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small 2}}] {\small Incremental innovations - products that provide
new features, benefits, or improvements to the existing technology
in the existing market }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small 1}}] {\small Imitative innovations - imitative products
are frequently new to the firm, but not new to the market }{\small \par}
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{{\small Product complexity}}

{\small Degree of complexity for the developed product ranging from
low complexity, e.g. a simple wooden chair, to high complexity, e.g.
an aircraft or a nuclear power plant. }{\small \par}


\paragraph*{{\small Industry}}

{\small Suitable industry from the list. }%
\end{minipage}}

\vfill{}

\pagebreak{}


\section*{Institutional design and production}

\framebox{\begin{minipage}[t]{1\columnwidth}%

\subsection*{{\small Legend}}


\paragraph*{{\small User Contribution}}

{\small Whether private persons or users are actively involved in
the development. }{\small \par}


\paragraph*{{\small Commercial Contribution}}

{\small Whether commercial companies are actively involved in the
development. }{\small \par}


\paragraph*{{\small Research contribution}}

{\small Whether research institutions are actively involved in the
development. }{\small \par}


\paragraph*{{\small Type of collaboration}}

{\small Type of development according to: }{\small \par}
\begin{itemize}
\item {\small Collective development of...}{\small \par}

\begin{itemize}
\item {\small one common product}\\
{\small if a community is commonly developing one product. }{\small \par}
\item {\small several common products}\\
{\small if a community is commonly developing several different products. }{\small \par}
\end{itemize}
\item {\small Published knowledge...}{\small \par}

\begin{itemize}
\item {\small with some collective developement}\\
{\small if instructions or ideas are published and others make comments
and suggestions. }{\small \par}
\item {\small without collective developement}\\
{\small if information is purely revealed. }{\small \par}
\end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

\paragraph*{{\small Activity}}

{\small Activity level in the community or developer group...}{\small \par}
\begin{itemize}
\item {\small from low (up to one interaction per month on average) }{\small \par}
\item {\small to high (daily interaction)}{\small \par}
\end{itemize}

\paragraph*{{\small Community communication}}

{\small Major communication channels used within the project community}{\small \par}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{{\small Face-to-face}}] {\small People tend to interact in person. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Mailinglists}}] {\small At least one mailinglist is used
frequently. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Chat}}] {\small The community has at least one active chat. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Board}}] {\small A board/discussion forum is used. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Other}}] {\small Other communication channels as wikis,
blogs, etc. have been established. }{\small \par}
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{{\small Degree of openness}}

{\small Parts of the product which are freely available: }{\small \par}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{{\small SW}}] {\small All software and other non-physical, content
parts are open source. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small HWI}}] {\small Hardware specifications and interfaces are
layed open. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Case}}] {\small If applicable the case design is available,
e.g. as CAD for download. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Mechanics}}] {\small Mechanical parts, circuits, designs,
etc. are freely available. }{\small \par}
\item [{{\small Entirety}}] {\small The project is revealing all available
information. }{\small \par}
\end{lyxlist}

\paragraph*{{\small Development driver}}

{\small Main drivers of the development, i.e. the group(s) of people
pushing forward the project. Related company or association refers
to a company closely related to the project, for example the investing
company. }{\small \par}


\paragraph*{{\small Production}}

{\small Entity responsible for production. Related company or assoc.
refers to an entity closely related to the project or with a production
mandate. \textquotedbl{}Outsourced\textquotedbl{} is whenever an external
party is paid for supplying components. }{\small \par}


\paragraph*{{\small Member's position}}

{\small OIP's source personal relationship to the project.}%
\end{minipage}}
